messageBody:
Michael wrote:
> J.B.,
>
> Thanks for the reply. I'm not exactly sure what you mean by
> "Monostate," but I understand your concern on the static methods.

A Monostate is like an inside-out Singleton: all its fields and methods
are class-level (static) so although it looks like a normal object, no
matter how many of them you instantiate, they all look the same. (There
is no instance-level data to differentiate different instances.) Any
class with all class-level methods is effectively a Monostate.

> My
> developers' group is meeting on Wednesday and one of the topics is
> going to be allowing my project to use Spring. If that happens, I will
> eliminate the AppProperties and have each component that needs
> properties have a setter for the specific property.

I would do that, anyway: with Spring or without, your application's
entry point should make the decision about where application properties
come from, then hand those property /values/ to the objects that need
them. (If you can't do this easily, then that might signal the part of
the design that needs attention next.)
